choices.B: It provides CLI access to the network device.
choices.D: It forwards traffic to the next hop.
choices.C: It looks up an egress interface in the forwarding information base.

questions.question_text: What is the function of the control plane?

discussion.content:
A is correct

The control plane is the part of a network that controls how data packets are forwarded — meaning how data is sent from one place to another. The process of creating a routing table, for example, is considered part of the control plane. Routers use various protocols to identify network paths, and they store these paths in routing tables.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
The answer to the question "What is the function of the control plane?" is: A. It exchanges routing table information.

The control plane is responsible for exchange of routing table information between routers . The control plane sets up and maintains the routing tables that the data plane uses to forward packets. It provides a way for routers to learn about the networks they are directly connected to, as well as about other networks that are reachable through other routers.
cat5e cant go more than 1GBps

Selected Answer: AC
A. 10GBASE-T:

Description: 10GBASE-T is designed for 10 Gigabit Ethernet over twisted pair copper cabling.
Maximum Data Rate: 10 Gbps.
Common Use: Suitable for high-speed Ethernet connections.
C. Cat 5e:

Description: Category 5e (Cat 5e) is a type of twisted pair cable designed for high signal integrity.
Maximum Data Rate: Up to 1 Gbps.
Common Use: Although not designed for 2.5-Gbps and 5-Gbps speeds, Cat 5e may support these speeds over shorter distances and is often used in practice for such connections.
Therefore, the suitable cable types for connecting an access point to the WLC when 2.5-Gbps and 5-Gbps speeds are required are likely to be a combination of 10GBASE-T (option A) and Cat 5e (option C).
Correct answers are A & C

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
A more viable option is to upgrade your Cat5e cable without ever touching a wall. This is the approach that Cisco and the NBASE-T Alliance have taken to give us an immediate and cost effective solution. Thanks to their work, there is now a solution where you can get 2.5 and even 5 Gbps across existing Cat5e cable.

https://www.mercadoit.com/blog/noticias-it/como-cisco-catalyst-multigigabit-puede-aumentar-las-velocidades-de-red/
cat 5e and base-T
Why not AB??

comments.content: i believed it is because it is for long haul, not like WLC will be set.

discussion.content:
With the inclusion of the IEEE 802.3bz standard you can even get more performance with your existing Cat5e cables. Under the standard of IEEE 802.3bz you can achieve up to 2.5GBase-T and 5GBase-T up to 328 Feet (100 meters). It's able to achieve this by having the layer of transmissions be based on 10GBase-T but perform at a lower signal rate. When lowering the signal rate it reduces the cabling requirements giving you the ability to perform this on Cat5e. While this is certainly obtainable it's not a guarantee. For Cat5e we can look to the baseline performance of 1Gb up to 328 Feet as the standard performance you can achieve and 2.5 or 5GBase-T being the performance under ideal environments including capable hardware.
https://infinity-cable-products.com/blogs/performance/what-is-the-cat5e-max-speed
So, Cat 5e could be the theoretically correct answer.
CAT5e and CAT6 can handle speeds of up to 1000 Mbps, or a Gigabit per second.

The use of proper cable types will directly affect the performance of the Catalyst 9136I (A cisco AP). Since this AP has 5-Gbps ports, the recommendation is to use either CAT6 or CAT 6a cable, which support speeds of up to 10 Gbps. CAT 5e cables can still be used; however, there may be an effect on the AP’s performance.
Since there is no option for Cat6 or Cat6e so answer should be 10G and Cat5e.

What is a benefit for external users who consume public cloud resources?

discussion.content: The question is formulated in a weird way... Or is it me?

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
C is correct.
Public cloud resources can be accessed over the public Internet not only over a dedicated WAN.

Selected Answer: C
C. Accessed over the Internet

Explanation:

The benefit for external users who consume public cloud resources is that these resources can be accessed over the Internet. Public cloud services are hosted by third-party providers on a global scale and are made available to users over the Internet. This provides flexibility and accessibility for users from different locations to access and use the cloud resources without the need for a dedicated WAN or being in the same data center as the resources.

Options A and D are not accurate for describing public cloud resources:

A. Public cloud resources are typically accessed over the public Internet, not necessarily over a dedicated WAN.
D. Public cloud resources are distributed across multiple data centers, and users can access them from anywhere with an Internet connection, not necessarily from the same data center.

discussion.content:
Just to add more info here:
A, .248 has a group size of 8. At a glance that's too small to include both .100 and .128.
.252 has a group size of 4. Same as above.
.224 seems large enough with a 32 group size, but if you subnet you'll find that .128 is a network address.

That leaves us with 255.255.255.0. Which gives us the first usable at .25.1 and the last usable at .25.254.

comments.content: You don't have to go over each answer. the SM of the new network has to be less than the SM of the individual networks.

If it helps anybody out you can always use the up range as well like for c 255.255.255.0 that is /24 which has 254 usable ips. Thats should for the range of 192.168.25.100 - 192.168.25.128 provided in the question

The range with /24 give us the 192.168.25.0 - 192.168.25.255 which covers those ips in questions just add your usable ips to the last octet to figure out range

comments.content:
we had 2 networks of /25 SM (192.168.25.0/25) and (192.168.25.128/25) they were merged into a larger network (192.168.25.0/24)

Note that 192.168.25.128/25 is not a vlaid IP address, since it is the network ID of the 2nd subnet of a /25 SM. 

After merging the two networks, it becomes valid (usable IP address range: 192.168.25.1-192.168.25.254)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The two pcs cannot communicate with one another because they lie in different subnets. To enable the communication between the two pcs, they must be in the same subnet. The solution is to use what is known as supernetting (merging smaller networks into a larger network.)
Option C will yield both addresses in the same subnet, therefore; communication between the two pcs is available. 

Option C is the only valid option since the SM for the new network has to be less than the SM of the individual small networks (because when you merge, you are reducing the number of networks.)

None of the options listed represent the correct subnet mask for these specific IP addresses (192.168.25.128/25 and 192.168.25.100/25) to communicate within the same subnet. The accurate subnet mask for these IP addresses within the same subnet should be 255.255.255.128 (/25).

Selected Answer: C
It's a wrong question. The question says different subnet, but C, which is the only possible answer, does not provide this.

Selected Answer: C
Use default class C mask

comments.content:
To enable communication between the two PCs in different subnets, the engineer needs to configure both PCs with the same network mask. In this case, the PCs have IP addresses 192.168.25.128/25 and 192.168.25.100/25, indicating that they are using a subnet mask of 255.255.255.128.

Therefore, the engineer must configure both PCs with the subnet mask 255.255.255.128 to ensure they are in the same subnet and can communicate with each other locally.

An engineer must update the configuration on two PCs in two different subnets to communicate locally with each other. One PC is configured with IP address
192.168.25.128/25 and the other with 192.168.25.100/25. Which network mask must the engineer configure on both PCs to enable the communication?

choices.D: Forwarding traffic to the next hop

questions.question_text: Which key function is provided by the data plane?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Explanation:

The data plane, also known as the forwarding plane, is responsible for the actual forwarding of data packets within a network. The key function of the data plane is to forward packets from the source to the destination based on the information in the forwarding table or forwarding information base (FIB). This involves making decisions on how to move the data through the network and ultimately forwarding it to the next hop in the network path.

Options A, B, and C are typically associated with the control plane:

A. Originating packets: This is a function of the control plane, where devices create or generate packets.
B. Exchanging routing table data: This is also a function of the control plane, where devices share routing information to build and update their routing tables.
C. Making routing decisions: This is a control plane function where decisions are made on how to route traffic based on the information gathered through routing protocols.

I think 'A. originating packets' is a misleading expression
Because the data plane sends packets

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
I remember it by saying " Hop on a (data) plane lol

Selected Answer: D
only answer could be, all other answer relates to control plane

The answer to the question "Which key function is provided by the data plane?" is: D. Forwarding traffic to the next hop

The data plane , also known as the forwarding plane, is responsible for the actual forwarding of data packets through a network. It consists of the hardware and software components in a network device that perform packet forwarding, routing, and switching. The data plane makes decisions about where packets should be forwarded to next and determines the appropriate ports to send them out. Therefore, the key function that is provided by the data plane is forwarding traffic to the next hop.
forwarding packets
